wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Among the approximately

6,000 languages

in the world, an average of 2 languages disappear each month.

Based on the documentary "Tongues of Heaven," Root Tongue introduces you to the

four filmmakers

as they record their struggle to cultivate their mother tongue in Taiwan and Hawai`i.

Root Tongue enables you to explore the challenges of language endangerment and

preservation

by experiencing and sharing stories of language loss and revival.

VIEW THEMATIC VIDEOS
(1–4 MINUTES IN LENGTH)

AFTER EACH VIDEO
PLAYS YOU WILL BE ASKED
A QUESTION

SUBMIT STORIES IN TEXT,
IMAGE, AUDIO, OR VIDEO

Visit the community gallery
to see other responses

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: marisa
item.content:encoded:
Learning Tools - 學習工具
  • Alilin Taiwan Indigenous ebooks - 臺灣原住民族電子書城 alilin.apc.gov.tw/tw
  • Heritage Language e-Paradise - 族語e樂園 web.klokah.tw
  • Modern Taiwanese Language learntaiwanese.org
  • PanLex Translator App panlex.org
  • Taiwan Indigenous Online Dictionary - 原住民族語言線上詞典 m-dictionary.apc.gov.tw
  • Ulukau Hawaiian Electronic Library ulukau.org

Research & Connecting - 研究和網絡聯繫
  • Administration for Native Americans Preservation and Maintenance Grants, Washington, D.C. www.acf.hhs.gov/ana/resource/native-languages-preservation-and-maintenance
  • Ancestral Visions of ʻĀina www.avakonohiki.org/
  • Indigenous Language Institute, Santa Fe, New Mexico www.ilinative.org
  • Language Documentation and Conservation Journal, Honolulu, Hawai‘i http://nflrc.hawaii.edu/ldc
  • Papakilo Database www.papakilodatabase.com
  • The Rosetta Project – The Long Now Foundation of Human Languages rosettaproject.org
  • Wenshui Atayal Language Learning Platform - 汶水泰雅語言學習網 http://117.56.81.183/taian_tech
Study - 學習
  • College of Hawaiian Language, University of Hawai‘i, Hilo www.olelo.hawaii.edu
  • Hawaiʻinuiākea School of Hawaiian Knowledge manoa.hawaii.edu/hshk

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: marisa
item.content:encoded: Among the 6,000 or so languages in the world, an average of 2 languages disappear each month. Because linguicide is generally a slow death, and sometimes not apparent until the last speaker is remaining, the dialogue and actions around language endangerment must be ongoing. ROOT TONGUE engages audiences motivated by the stories and issues raised in the film TONGUES OF HEAVEN, co-directed by Anita Chang, An-Chi Chen, Kainoa Kaupu, Hau`oli Waiau and Shin-Lan Yu. In the documentary, four young indigenous women from Taiwan and Hawai`i use video cameras to share their challenges in learning the languages of their forebears before they go extinct. They ask themselves and their community: What do you lose when you lose your native language? In this ROOT TONGUE app, clips from the documentary and companion questions allow you to explore the challenges of language endangerment and preservation by sharing your own perspective through dialogue and creative uploads of your videos, images, audio and writings. You can also access educational and community resources pertaining to language preservation. We welcome your suggestions for language preservation and learning resources. We hope you will join us in sharing your challenges, promises and successes, and that you will find meaningful connections here. Who We Are Interactive Producer Michella Rivera-Gravage is dedicated to working with compelling and evocative stories to move and change people around a variety of social issues. Over the past 10 years, she has produced innovative moving images, new media and participatory projects within the Public Media sector, specializing in social and interactive media. Michella is currently designing and producing interactive media, developing social media strategies. She earned an MFA in Digital Art & New Media from UC Santa Cruz. michellaforever.com Project Director Anita Chang is an independent filmmaker, educator and writer. The issue of a language not being passed down to the next generation has always been a part of her life. Her first language was Taiwanese or Minnanese, but she gradually lost her ability to speak it when she started learning English in the U.S., a common phenomenon for second-generation children of immigrants to the U.S. Anita’s award-winning works have screened and broadcast internationally, and been presented at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, Walker Arts Center, Museum of Fine Arts Houston, and National Museum of Women. Her documentaries are distributed by Women Make Movies, Third World Newsreel, the Center for Asian American Media, Kanopy Streaming, and Taiwan Public Television. anitachangworks.com Our dedicated team in Taiwan consists of linguistics consultants Amy P. Lee and Apay Yang, and Social Media consultant Yu-Chao Huang from National Dong Hwa University. Our magical design studio is Otherwise Co. and our development team is the ever-brilliant Jessica Yazbek and whip-smart Marisa Wilson. Project Director Statement by Anita Chang It wasn’t until I started living and working in Taiwan that I learned of the incredible diversity of languages spoken on the island. During the first two years while I was teaching film in the Department of Indigenous Languages and Communications at National Dong Hwa University located in eastern Taiwan, I was made aware of an on-going lament by my students in their limited or lack of ability to speak their mother tongue, their linguistic heritage being from one or more of the 16 distinct indigenous languages, Minnanese and/or Hakka. Keenly aware that they and their peers are not speaking their heritage languages, they foresaw a bleak future for the survival of these languages. This is how the idea of the film came about, and a production method that involved young co-directors to collaboratively tackle this issue of language endangerment arising out of Taiwan’s complex colonial history. The production inevitably evolved a compelling exchange with young indigenous peoples from Hawai`i, known worldwide for its language revitalization efforts. Root Tongue funders Big Ideas @ Berkeley Creative Capital Indiegogo Donors National Dong Hwa University North American Taiwanese Women’s Association Porter College Graduate Arts Research San Francisco Arts Commission Taiwanese United Fund University of California Institute for Research in the Arts

item.title: Privacy & Terms of Use
item.dc:creator: michella
item.content:encoded: In order to help facilitate a positive environment, here are a few important reminders: All uploaded content must belong to the individuals who agreed to participate. When you contribute to a public area of this app, some of your personal information that you submit will be made available to the general public. Therefore, we recommend that you review all your content prior to submitting it to ensure its accuracy and ensure it contains no information that you are not comfortable sharing. Root Tongue will not share any of your personal login or user profile information. We welcome uploads and comments that are thoughtful and respectful, and we reserve the right to remove content that is not civil. If you have any questions about this privacy statement, your personal information, or the practices of this site, you can contact us at root.tongue@gmail.com.

item.title: 關於
item.dc:creator: wali
item.content:encoded: 在世界上6000種左右的語言中, 平均每月有2種語言消失。由於語言滅絕通常是一種緩慢的死亡, 最後一位使用者, 所以對於語言瀕危的對話和行動必須持續進行。 由張文馨，陳安琪，Kainoa Kaupu、Hau`oli Waiau和余欣蘭共同執導的電影「TONGUES OF HEAVEN」所敘述的故事和帶出的問題將促使觀眾使用 ROOT TONGUE。在紀錄片中, 來自台灣和夏威夷的四位年輕原住民婦女使用攝影機在前輩們的語言即將滅絕之前分享挑戰。他們問自己和他們的社區：當你失去母語時你失去了什麼？ 在這款ROOT TONGUE應用程式 , 我們鼓勵您透過上傳您的影音、圖片和文字分享您的視角與大家進行對話, 共同探索語言瀕危和保存的挑戰。您還可以接收有關語言保存的教育和社區資源。我們歡迎您提出保護語言和學習資源的建議。 我們希望您能夠與我們一起分享您的挑戰, 承諾和成就, 並且您會在這裡找到有意義的聯繫。 關於我們 互動製作人Michella Rivera-Gravage  致力於引人入勝和令人回味的故事, 以感動和改變人們的各種社會問題。在過去的十年裡, 她在公共媒體部門製作了創新的移動圖像, 新媒體和參與性計劃, 專門從事社交媒體和互動媒體。Michella目前正在設計和製作互動媒體, 開發社交媒體策略。她在加利福尼亞州聖塔克魯斯的數字藝術與新媒體部門獲得了MFA。michellaforever.com 計劃總監張文馨是獨立電影製作人, 教育家和作家。一種語言不被傳遞給下一代的問題一直是她生活的一部分。她的第一語言是台灣話或閩南話, 但當她在美國開始學習英語時, 她漸漸失去了說台灣話的能力, 這是移民到美國的第二代兒童的普遍現象。張文馨的獲獎作品已在國際上進行篩选和播放, 並曾在惠特尼美國藝術博物館, 耶爾布埃納藝術中心, 沃克藝術中心, 休士頓美術博物館和國家婦女博物館展出。她的紀錄片由婦女製作電影, 第三世界新聞，亞裔美國媒體中心, Kanopy Streaming媒體和台灣公共電視台發行。anitachangworks.com 我們在台灣的專業團隊由語言學顧問李佩容和湯愛玉以及來自國立東華大學的社群媒體顧問黃毓超組成。 我們的神奇設計工作室是 Otherwise Co. 我們的開發團隊是非常傑出的Jessica Yazbek, 富有機智又聰明的Marisa Wilson和Wali Hassan Jafferi。 計劃總監張文馨的聲明 直到我開始在台灣生活和工作, 我才了解到島上所說的語言令人難以置信的多樣性。在台灣東部東華大學民族語言與傳播系教導電影的前兩年, 我意識到我的學生對他們有限或缺乏說母語的能力而持續哀傷, 他們的母語來自16種不同的原住民族語言中的一種或多種, 即閩南話以及客家話。清楚地意識到他們和他們的同齡人不會說他們的母語, 他們預料到這些語言的生存會有一個黯淡的未來。這就是電影的想法是如何產生的, 還有一種製作方法, 就是讓年輕人共同導演合作解決由於台灣複雜的殖民歷史而產生的語言瀕危問題。這個製作無可避免地與來自夏威夷的年輕原住民族人民形成了一種引人注目的交流，這種為了語言復興而努力的交流也因此聞名全世界。 資助者 創意資本 舊金山藝術委員會 加州大學藝術研究院 在柏克萊的大創意 波特大學研究生藝術研究 北美台灣婦女協會 台灣聯合基金

item.title: 條款
item.dc:creator: wali
item.content:encoded: 為了促進正向使用環境，以下是一些重要提醒： 所有上傳內容必須屬於同意參與的個人。 當您為此公共區域做出貢獻時, 您提交的某些個人信息將會提供給公眾。因此, 我們建議您在提交之前檢查所有用戶內容以確保其準確性，並確保其中不包含您希望共享的訊息。否則, Root Tongue不會分享您的任何個人訊息。 所有上傳內容和評論必須以負責與同理的態度完成。 我們歡迎善意和尊重的評論與上傳內容，但也保留刪除不當內容的權利。 如果您對本隱私聲明, 您的個人訊息或本網站的做法有任何疑問, 可以透過root.tongue@gmail.com與我們聯繫。

item.title: Filipino(t) - An Identity Rediscovered
item.dc:creator: ethanalonzo
item.content:encoded:
While my body, blood, and soul is Filipino, I wasn't necessarily raised Filipino. I grew up in Salinas, California, which is a predominately Mexican city. While Salinas has a rising population of Asians, it wasn't always like that. In fact, I was the only Asian kid until high school. After years of trying to assimilate, meeting other Filipino kids felt almost foreign to me. In a way, I didn't look how I acted and vise versa. Looking back, a lot of the things those kids said and did regarding Asians was actually really offensive, but, since I didn't associate myself with the culture until later in life, I saw no problem with it. It wasn't until college when I felt the full effect of my efforts to fit in with my peers.
It was like playing catch up, learning all these new things from a culture I decided to ignore for so long. I rediscovered my love for the food I grew bored of. The language sounded like music whenever I randomly heard it on the street. I gained a certain pride when I saw a Filipino media creator get noticed. While I am still learning about myself, my family, and where I come from, there will always be that gap of my life where I wasn't "fully" Filipino.

item.title: Big and Small Bhashas of India
item.dc:creator: lux3005@yahoo.com
item.content:encoded:
Sidewalk art in California by VJJ age 6 and 1/2
Honoring the many mother tongues of India big and small

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
My mom was born in Germany and moved to the states in the late 1970s. She raised my sister and me with every effort to interest us in the German language. Cultural tradition and history were less important to her, though we did take folk dancing lessons (mostly, I think, because my Grandma, originally from Austria, had handmade us dirndls!). Up until about seventh grade, my mom sent us to German-language school on the weekends and in the summers.
I remember few things about the school itself, except for some surrounding details. First, mom would pretty much always bribe us into going with either homemade chocolate chip pancakes or the promise of a big sweet breakfast at the diner around the corner from our house. Second, my sister and I got to take a school bus to the language summer camp, which I always thought was pretty fun. My sister studied a lot more than I did. I found it really frustrating that the language didn't just stick with me like English did.
Of course, as an adult I realized how much had actually stayed with me...words, of course, but also manners of speech and expressions, as well as pronunciations, like the rather inscrutable "ch" sound in a word like "Milch" (Milk), or the difference between the "u" and "ü."
A big part of my resistance was that it was always hard to square my ability (lacking) with my affection or interest (unbounded!) in the idea of a different kind of cultural landscape, especially when we visited our family in Germany. What I mean is that, I always thought it was really special to be able to travel abroad and to be really taken in by a country without necessarily understanding all of its linguistic codes. In other words, Germany felt different than the US. It smelled different. The soda had a different flavor. The trees were different. I loved being there! But, I hated speaking German. It was frustrating and felt like an impossible task.
Now, as an adult, I understand that speaking another language is another way of experiencing the world...or at least of representing that experience. And, that is something I value a great deal, especially as a conduit to getting to know other people.
I wish I had taken that more seriously as a kid and I am sorry for my mom for all those pancakes she had to make us. I guess she does have a whole lot of pictures of us in cute outfits, though.
語言關乎我是誰,我來自哪裡，是自我認同。

item.content:encoded: Because the films title is tongue f heaven, here is a pic about how tongue of heaven spread here ！and I speak my mother tongue pretty well ！

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I think that language can be learnt and used well unless it's widely used. Most of the time there is no that kind of language environment for using it. Although we youth have tried to learn our mother tongue, we may easily forget it since it can't be used when we are with different friends from various places with different languages.

item.title: Untitled
item.dc:creator: Scarfknitter@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
語言就如同時間，既是歷史，也是未來，更是我們沈浸於其中的當下。隨時間留下痕跡也隨時間流逝，而我們或許毫無知覺。
語言是日常是與人相處的根基，由此共同擁有，發展及延伸。

item.title: lorena
item.dc:creator: lpinopro@yahoo.com
item.content:encoded: I speak one mother tongue and part of another mother tongue that existed before this country was named.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: we are all still very primitive. acting, reacting, defending, protecting, yet mostly dismissive (lost in the reprogramming) of our innate senses preventing us from truly seeing.
I speak my mother tongue, English, with almost everyone I know. I speak french with a few people who do not speak English.

I don't speak my "native" language because I can't know what that is. As a Black person my culture was taken from my family through slavery and colonization so I dont know what my true roots are besides American.

item.title: 你的社區
item.dc:creator: wali

item.title: 青年
item.dc:creator: wali
item.content:encoded: 你覺得你的語言消失的危機程度如何？你如何讓你的語言活著？

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I have Italian and Mexican roots. I speak English and am currently learning Spanish. As for determining my mother tongue that would require me to research my ancestry as there were over 60 languages spoken in Mexico at one point and I have no knowledge of what my mother tongue is or if it still exists. I do not speak Italian. The preservation of Italian, Spanish and English all exist and are under little threat as far as I know

Without language, I can still know tradition. I resonate deeply with food. Through the medium of food, I would continue to share my cultural heritage. By seeping my culture into that of the collective, it will be infinite in expansiveness and longevity. By identifying as a human community and a child of the earth, I will always know history, home, source, and vital energy exchange.

I am of Navajo and Hawaiian descent. I do not speak my mother tongue, but I do wish to speak them both. I come from a household where Diné bizaad (Navajo language) was not spoken very often, mostly small phrases or basic words. As far as the Hawaiian language, I knew very minimal amounts of words. My efforts to "re-learn" Diné bizaad right now are taking language classes at my university and reinforcing it back at home in the household.

I speak fluent English, but my mother tongue is Lithuanian. Although I know next to nothing about it, I am quite proud of being Lithuanian. As far as i know, I am 100% Lithuanian. I was born in Šiauliai, Lithuania, and I was adopted, brought here to the United States when I was three. I don't know much about my heritage, or my roots, but I hope to learn about them someday. I know so little, I've actually just learned I've been butchering the pronunciation of my hometown all this time..I do not speak my mother tongue, but I very strongly yearn to someday, possibly during, or after college, and learn more about my roots, where I came from, and what it means to be Lithuanian. Even when I can count to ten in Lithuanian, i have such a sense of pride in doing so.

item.content:encoded: Beyond my parents, I never thought I could hear my mother tongue spoken elsewhere in the U.S. But having discovered a welcoming Taiwanese American community rich with elder speakers I want to find time and a way to relearn my first language with them. They are like home away from home.

item.title: A Taiwanese American Speaker Community
item.dc:creator: zhangwenshin@yahoo.com
item.content:encoded: Beyond my immediate family, I never thought I would hear Minnanese spoken in the U.S. until I met a community of elder speakers in the South Bay. I want to find time and a way to relearn my first language with them--a home away from home.

item.title: Big and Small Bhashas of India
item.dc:creator: lux3005@yahoo.com
item.content:encoded:
Sidewalk art in California by VJJ age 6 and 1/2
Honoring the many mother tongues of India big and small

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I don't speak my "native" language because I can't know what that is. As a Black person my culture was taken from my family through slavery and colonization so I dont know what my true roots are besides American.

Without language, I can still know tradition. I resonate deeply with food. Through the medium of food, I would continue to share my cultural heritage. By seeping my culture into that of the collective, it will be infinite in expansiveness and longevity. By identifying as a human community and a child of the earth, I will always know history, home, source, and vital energy exchange.

item.title: Family
item.dc:creator: ychen83@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Separate childhood & teenage backgrounds, but still it is common culture/mother tongue that bonds us like Family.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I speak fluent English, but my mother tongue is Lithuanian. Although I know next to nothing about it, I am quite proud of being Lithuanian. As far as i know, I am 100% Lithuanian. I was born in Šiauliai, Lithuania, and I was adopted, brought here to the United States when I was three. I don't know much about my heritage, or my roots, but I hope to learn about them someday. I know so little, I've actually just learned I've been butchering the pronunciation of my hometown all this time..I do not speak my mother tongue, but I very strongly yearn to someday, possibly during, or after college, and learn more about my roots, where I came from, and what it means to be Lithuanian. Even when I can count to ten in Lithuanian, i have such a sense of pride in doing so.

item.title: lorena
item.dc:creator: lpinopro@yahoo.com
item.content:encoded: I speak one mother tongue and part of another mother tongue that existed before this country was named.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: we are all still very primitive. acting, reacting, defending, protecting, yet mostly dismissive (lost in the reprogramming) of our innate senses preventing us from truly seeing.
I speak my mother tongue, English, with almost everyone I know. I speak french with a few people who do not speak English.

I have Italian and Mexican roots. I speak English and am currently learning Spanish. As for determining my mother tongue that would require me to research my ancestry as there were over 60 languages spoken in Mexico at one point and I have no knowledge of what my mother tongue is or if it still exists. I do not speak Italian. The preservation of Italian, Spanish and English all exist and are under little threat as far as I know

I am of Navajo and Hawaiian descent. I do not speak my mother tongue, but I do wish to speak them both. I come from a household where Diné bizaad (Navajo language) was not spoken very often, mostly small phrases or basic words. As far as the Hawaiian language, I knew very minimal amounts of words. My efforts to "re-learn" Diné bizaad right now are taking language classes at my university and reinforcing it back at home in the household.

item.title: My pic
item.dc:creator: karimahmad@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: My pic

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
My mom was born in Germany and moved to the states in the late 1970s. She raised my sister and me with every effort to interest us in the German language. Cultural tradition and history were less important to her, though we did take folk dancing lessons (mostly, I think, because my Grandma, originally from Austria, had handmade us dirndls!). Up until about seventh grade, my mom sent us to German-language school on the weekends and in the summers.
I remember few things about the school itself, except for some surrounding details. First, mom would pretty much always bribe us into going with either homemade chocolate chip pancakes or the promise of a big sweet breakfast at the diner around the corner from our house. Second, my sister and I got to take a school bus to the language summer camp, which I always thought was pretty fun. My sister studied a lot more than I did. I found it really frustrating that the language didn't just stick with me like English did.
Of course, as an adult I realized how much had actually stayed with me...words, of course, but also manners of speech and expressions, as well as pronunciations, like the rather inscrutable "ch" sound in a word like "Milch" (Milk), or the difference between the "u" and "ü."
A big part of my resistance was that it was always hard to square my ability (lacking) with my affection or interest (unbounded!) in the idea of a different kind of cultural landscape, especially when we visited our family in Germany. What I mean is that, I always thought it was really special to be able to travel abroad and to be really taken in by a country without necessarily understanding all of its linguistic codes. In other words, Germany felt different than the US. It smelled different. The soda had a different flavor. The trees were different. I loved being there! But, I hated speaking German. It was frustrating and felt like an impossible task.
Now, as an adult, I understand that speaking another language is another way of experiencing the world...or at least of representing that experience. And, that is something I value a great deal, especially as a conduit to getting to know other people.
I wish I had taken that more seriously as a kid and I am sorry for my mom for all those pancakes she had to make us. I guess she does have a whole lot of pictures of us in cute outfits, though.

item.content:encoded: Because the films title is tongue f heaven, here is a pic about how tongue of heaven spread here ！and I speak my mother tongue pretty well ！

item.title: Untitled
item.dc:creator: Scarfknitter@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
語言就如同時間，既是歷史，也是未來，更是我們沈浸於其中的當下。隨時間留下痕跡也隨時間流逝，而我們或許毫無知覺。
語言是日常是與人相處的根基，由此共同擁有，發展及延伸。

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I think that language can be learnt and used well unless it's widely used. Most of the time there is no that kind of language environment for using it. Although we youth have tried to learn our mother tongue, we may easily forget it since it can't be used when we are with different friends from various places with different languages.

item.title: Wish I listened more to Lola conchita
item.dc:creator: michella

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: My grandma (lola conchita) taught me so much about my culture including many Ilonggo words. I wish I paid more attention when I was younger!

item.title: 團圓夜
item.dc:creator: rain19891222@hotmail.com
item.content:encoded: 每次農曆新年的團圓夜，總是會留一個位置給逝世近10年的阿公，感覺他一直與我們一起，喊著：恁瓏緊來甲！

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 語言關乎我是誰,我來自哪裡，是自我認同。

item.title: My Mother's Mother
item.dc:creator: dchein
item.content:encoded: For a long time I wanted to forget how to speak Chinese. It made me different when what I wanted was to fit in. It wasn't until I began visiting Taiwan when I was a little older that I became aware of how important my first language was. I struggled to communicate with my family beyond the superficial small talk. I wanted to ask my grandmother about her life, but stumbled to find the words. Without Chinese, a connection to my heritage would be broken. Now, my grandmother has passed, but I have made a commitment to study Chinese to keep the connection alive.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This story speaks to me, even though I’ve never experienced anything similar. Just the thought of being unable to communicate with a loved one becaue of a langue barrier tears me apart. Speaking English is definitely a privilege I never thought about. Everyone across the globe is forced to study English, so the fear of losing a language has never been apparent.

item.title: Loss
item.dc:creator: chi_la
item.content:encoded: I failed to learn to speak my mother tongue when I was little and I missed the chance to get to know my grandparents and the live they lived through.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I speak my mother tongue a little bit, not quite fluently. It's a shame that I didn't know how to speak my mother tongue when I was little (I learned to speak it when i was in college) and thus I couldn't communicate with my grandparents (of my mother's side) before they deceased.

Falter
I know of them. These cultures that "apparently" I belong. It is obvious to me, that I do not belong there or here. I belong to me.
In first introductions, people ask about your shoes, your haircut, or something surface-y. It's a natural occurrence in American culture as a way of easing into a conversation (hopefully one of meaning). Throughout my life, I have been asked, "What are you?" I know what they want to know. The names of the races that make up my face: Cantonese, Okinawan, Japanese, Scottish & Irish. And by the end of the list, they'll say something like, "How exotic." Or "You mixed always look so interesting." I'm not offended by it, it's just uncomfortable. Today, I say, "I am human" and I leave it at that because they are only concerned with the contours of my face, and I'd rather not discuss it. And deep down, I feel awkward when I hardly know anything about "my" cultures, because these cultures are clearly not my own. My roots are there, but I am a third generation American with parents who neglected to teach me their languages because they hardly knew them, themselves. I don't know any language other than those that have allowed me to communicate my feelings (art, film, writing, performance). I do not belong to these cultures and they do not belong to me, and yet, many define me by them. How can I resonate, let alone, explain in depth to others what I do not know? I don't want to do these cultures an injustice. I appreciate these cultures that have "created me", and I'm inclined to learn about them, but first and foremost, I am me, not a race to define. It took me a long time to realize this, since my American consumerist culture had brought me up to believe that this was the most important and defining factor of my identity. I now know that I am more than an interesting face.

item.title: A birthday celebration in the mother tongue
item.dc:creator: EEK
item.content:encoded: While Taiwanese Hokkien is no longer discouraged from being learned and spoken in Taiwan, the years of its suppression by the KMT appears to have had a lasting effect as it is hard to find books and online resources to learn it. I fear that without enough resources readily available, the language will deterioate over time with each generation of Taiwanese living outside Taiwan.

item.title: A visit to Ah-ma
item.dc:creator: EEK
item.content:encoded: A visit to Ah-ma (grandma) in Taiwan. A gentle, generous spirit that brightened the lives of everyone around her. Her mother tongue is Taiwanese Hokkien which she taught to my mother, who taught to me. When the KMT forcefully took over Taiwan in 1949, they forced the Taiwanese people to learn Mandarin Chinese and made it difficult to learn Taiwanese Hokkien. She also speaks Mandarin Chinese, Japanese and a little bit of English.

item.title: wanting to learn a language
item.dc:creator: SteveF
item.content:encoded: Filmmaker Jia Zhangke speaks a facile kind of Mandarin that makes me want to study it again. In learning a language, how much is necessity, how much is choice/desire?

item.title: Ahma & I
item.dc:creator: zenqi
item.content:encoded: Here's a picture of my paternal grandmother and I. Luckily, I was able to become somewhat fluent in Mandarin before she passed and I was so grateful to hear stories about how she and grandpa met. However, there was still a slight distance in speaking Mandarin with grandma because her first language was Taiwanese (Minnanhua), then Japanese, then Mandarin. I'm currently studying Japanese now and improving my Mandarin. I'd like to pick up Taiwanese again (I spoke it as a child), but the incentives and number of resources are much higher for Mandarin and Japanese. I recently met a Jewish-American man in his 20s that learned Taiwanese and Hakka for fun and I feel newly inspired to relearn Taiwanese as an adult. I think guilt and shame are not great ways to push someone into learning a language, I think interest/fun (through books, movies, travel) and love (family. partners) are better ways in.

item.title: A Marshallese Interview
item.dc:creator: zhangwenshin@yahoo.com
item.content:encoded: In my interview with Marie Maddison in Majuro, she explained that her knowledge of Marshallese ways of being came with learning the language from elders, after returning from college in the U.S. An example is notions of governance: “We have the chiefs and the braves. We don’t say workers, we say braves. The word for brave is ‘kajjuur’ and the word for chief is ‘irooj.’ The word ‘irooj’ comes from two root words ‘er’ which is ‘them;’ ‘irooj’ means those people make up the chief. And ‘kajjurr,’ the braves, it comes from two words, ‘joor’ is pillar. So when you build a pillar or foundation, that is the braves, and without the foundation there is no chief. Those are the words I was taught by an older woman. And that is where the culture really is. You don’t learn this in school.”

During their exchange visit to Hawai`i, collaborating filmmaker Kainoa invites Anita Chang, An-Chi Chen and Shin-Lan Yu to her fishing village in Miloli`i.

After meeting their Hawaiian collaborators Kainoa Kaupu and Hau`oli Waiau, Anita Chang, An-Chi Chen and Shin-Lan Yu visit the renowned Living Hawaiian Life-Force School, a K-12 immersion school in Hilo on the Big Island.
In Hawai`i the four women shared their footage with each other. Here, fellow filmmaker Hau`oli Waiau talks about learning Hawaiian.
Anita Chang, An-Chi Chen and Shin-Lan Yu interview filmmaker Hau`oli Waiau and her mother at their home on O`ahu.
Near the end of their trip to Hawai`i, filmmaker An-Chi Chen reflects on whether language preservation is necessary for her.
Back in Taiwan from Hawai`i, one day filmmaker Shin-Lan Yu finds herself alone in her mountain village.
Back in Taiwan from Hawai`i, filmmaker An-Chi Chen reflects on the importance of the mother tongue but the lack of motivation to learn it.
In the last scene of the documentary, filmmaker Shin-Lan Yu asks her mother a question.
在紀錄片的最後一幕中, 電影導演余欣蘭問她的母親一個問題。
從Hawai`i回到台灣, 導演陳安琪反思了母語的重要性, 但缺乏學習的動力。
從夏威夷回到台灣 , 有一天 , 電影導演余欣蘭在山村里獨處。
在他們到夏威夷旅行接近結束時, 電影導演陳安琪反思了語言保存對她是否必要。
張文馨, 陳安琪和余欣蘭在O'ahu的家中採訪導演Hau`oli Waiau和她的母親。
在夏威夷, 四位女性彼此分享他們的影片。在這裡, 同行電影製片人 Hau`oli Waiau 談到了瞭解夏威夷一事。
在與夏威夷合作者 Kainoa Kaupu 和 Hau`oli Waiau 會面後, 張文馨, 陳安琪和余欣蘭會見了著名的 Living Hawaiian Life-Force School, 這是位於大島 Hilo 的K-12沉浸式學校。
在與夏威夷的交流訪問中, 合作電影製作人Kainoa邀請張文馨, 陳安琪和余欣蘭到她在Miloli`i的漁村。
魯凱語言活動家Suliape（賴女士）與電影製作人陳安琪進行了交談。
電影製作人陳安琪和余欣蘭一起拜訪了他們的同伴閻芬芬, 他剛剛走上振興她的族語 的路線, 卡那卡那富語, 約有10個人能說這個母語。
藍艷芬帶著電影製作人張文馨, 陳安琪和余欣蘭與你的祖父一起走過她的山村, 他是10位能說卡那卡那富語言之一。
電影製作人陳安琪採訪了她村里的魯凱語言活動家 Suliape。
在台灣屏東的五台村漫步時, 電影製作人陳安琪思考學習母語的挑戰。
電影製作人陳安琪問她的叔叔一個問題。
電影製作人陳安琪問她的父親一個問題。
電影製片人陳安琪介紹她的多語言家庭, 並分享她如何努力保持她的語言能力。
網路互動平台Root Tongue奠基於紀錄片「天堂的語言」, 它從這個開場景開始。
